column1: #Text=prompt_engine: Evaluate your model using advanced prompt strategies
#Text=New medical SOTA models available in Hugginface!
#Text=- [2024/09] [**Boosting Healthcare LLMs Through Retrieved Context**](https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.15127) is now available in Arxiv!
#Text=- [2024/05] [**Aloe: A Family of Fine-tuned Open Healthcare LLMs**](https://arxiv.org/abs/2405.01886) is now available in Arxiv!

#Text=This repository serves as a comprehensive platform for evaluating large language models (LLMs) utilizing diverse prompt engineering techniques aimed at enhancing performance on medical benchmarks.
#Text=Our goal is to explore how prompt engineering impact LLMs' accuracy, reliability, and overall usefulness in addressing complex medical scenarios.
#Text=This repo was first created to support the [Aloe](https://huggingface.co/HPAI-BSC/Llama3-Aloe-8B-Alpha) model.
#Text=Central to our investigation were efforts to exploit the inherent reasoning capabilities of LLMs by employing sophisticated prompt engineering approaches towards medical applications.
#Text=- **Self-Consistency Chain-of-Thought (SC-CoT)**: An iterative process wherein the LLM generates plausible explanations supporting each proposed solution before settling on a final answer.
#Text=By encouraging systematic thinking, SC-CoT helps enhance both the confidence and veracity of generated responses
#Text=- [**Medprompt**](https://github.com/microsoft/promptbase): A technique proposed by Microsoft, extending the traditional SC-COT.
#Text=Medprompt introduces additional features specifically targeted at refining LLM behavior in medical settings.
#Text=One key enhancement involves randomly shuffling provided choices before soliciting the LLM's response, thereby discouraging biases arising from predictable option orderings.

#Text=Furthermore, integrating relevant case studies or "K nearest neighbor" (Knn) few-shot examples directly into prompts allows LLMs to learn from analogous situations and draw parallels between them, ultimately fostering better-rounded judgments.

#Text=- **OpenMedprompt**: We aim to go beyond traditional Multiple-Choice Question-Answer approaches by introducing a novel strategy that enhances the generation of more accurate and reliable open-ended responses.
#Text=To achieve this, we propose two innovative methods focused on consensus-building and answer refinement:
#Text=    - **OM-ER (OpenMedprompt with Ensemble Refining)**: Leverages the diversity of multiple generated answers to produce a refined and more accurate final response.
#Text=It involves generating ùëÅ initial answers with randomized temperature and top_p parameters, incorporating ùêæ relevant examples from the database into the prompt.
#Text=Then, the LLM synthesizes these ùëÅ answers into a single, refined response
#Text=- **OM-SR (OpenMedprompt with Self-reflection)**: This strategy employs a feedback loop to improve the generated answer.
#Text=It begins by generating an initial answer using the ùêæ most similar examples from the database.
#Text=Then, it performs ùëÅ iterations of self-reflection, where the model generates feedback on its previous response and produces an improved answer based on this feedback.
#Text=We integrate attribute scores from ArmoRM-Llama3-8B, a reward model along with the critique model‚Äôs reflection as an external feedback to guide answer generation.
#Text=To effectively implement these novel techniques, we developed a specialized framework centered around accelerated inference speed and efficient data storage & retrieval mechanisms.
#Text=- [**VLLM**](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm): Fast Inference Very Large Language Model ibrary to facilitate rapid generation of responses in a efficient way.
#Text=- Vector database:  Vector database solution to facilitate the storage and computation of vector similarities required for setting up the Medprompt technique.
#Text=Both frameworks work in the self-hosted mode, storing the database locally under the "databases" path.
#Text=We integrated two different vector database solutions:
#Text=Open-source embedding database, focused on the simplicity and efficiency. only dense vectors are allowed
#Text=- [**Qdrant**](https://qdrant.tech/): Embedding database focused on production-ready service with a convenient API.
#Text=It allows to use the database client by creating a docker image, using the local memory or in the cloud.
#Text=In our implementation we use the local memory.
#Text=We recommend to use this database only when dealing with Sparse Vectors.
#Text=Indeed, central to our approach was providing flexibility and adaptability in executing diverse tasks related to evaluating LLMs on medical benchmarks.

#Text=Users can easily configure a wide array of parameters according to their unique experimental designs or preferences by modifying simple YAML configuration files found within the designated config directory.
#Text=A requirements file with the necessary packages is provided to install and execute this repo.
#Text=First, make sure you configured properly a YAML configuration file.
#Text=To configure an execution of Medprompt or Self-Consistency CoT ensembling, a configuration file must be created.
#Text=Some examples are included in the "/configs" folder.
#Text=The configuration files define the parameters of the execution, model configuration, and sampling parameters.
#Text=More details about the configuration parameters can be found [here](configs).
#Text=We include the following medical datasets formatted in the required format:
#Text=Other datasets can be used if they are in the required format.
#Text=More details can be found in [Datasets](medprompt/datasets) section.
#Text=Each execution is stored in a specific path that is determined by the parameters selected and under the "outputs/" directory.
#Text=The subdirectories generated will have this format:
#Text=                            ----- Kk (5k, 4k...) + _database and/or _reranker if they exist in confg
#Text=In the "val" directory are saved the generations of Medprompt of the training/validation sets, that are used for selecting the knn similar examples for the test questions.
#Text=It is only generated when running Medprompt without database.
#Text=Each final directory will store the generations file of the exection, named "generations.json".
#Text=The generations file holds the information of the question and the corresponding generations.
#Text=The format of the generations is the following:
#Text=        "description": "DESCRITION OF THE QUESTION = QUESTION + SHUFFLED OPTIONS",
#Text=        "original_answer": "A", # Original option selection of the model response
#Text=        "result": "C",  # Option selection in the original options order
#Text=        "order": "BDAC",    # Order of the options in the description
#Text=        "retries": 1,   # Number of retries until the model returned a valid answer
#Text=        "prompt_tokens": 684,   # Number of tokens in the prompt
#Text=        "metrics": {    # Time information of the inference returned by VLLM
#Text=When the generations of an execution, the evaluation procedure starts, and generates the results storing 3 extra files:
#Text=- Number of examples evaluated and the **accuracy**
#Text=    - Number of answers that the model has not been able to answer correctly (_no_pased_answers_)
#Text=    - Number of draws in the majority voting (and how many resulted or not in a correct prediction) (_draws_)
#Text=    - Number of times the model predicted each option (ABCD...)
#Text=    - Statistics regarding the number of generated tokens, time spend inferencing the model, lengths of the prompts...
#Text=    - Timestamp of the evaluation execution (_date_) and the last modification timestamp of the generations.json file (_generation_date_)
#Text=- times_TIMESTAMP.json: Saves information about the time spent in each stage of the process.
#Text=- incorrect_questions_TIMESTAMP: Stores the questions that resulted in an incorrect result after the majority voting.
#Text=When running Medprompt, we allow the utilization of custom databases.
#Text=When a database is specified in the configuration, the generation of training/validation CoT examples will be skipped and the examples of the databases will be used instead.
#Text=However, the database must have the same format as the output generations file, detailed above.
#Text=Feel free to generate your custom databases to test the Medprompt technique.
#Text=If you use this repository in a published work, please cite the following papers as sources:
#Text=Boosting Healthcare LLMs Through Retrieved Context. arXiv preprint arXiv:2409.15127.
#Text=      title={Boosting Healthcare LLMs Through Retrieved Context},
#Text=      author={Jordi Bayarri-Planas and Ashwin Kumar Gururajan and Dario Garcia-Gasulla},
